course.name: Data Structures and Algorithms (T3 2025)
course.description: Core UNSW computer science course on algorithm analysis, sorting, abstract data types, graphs, hashing, and tries, with an emphasis on reasoning about correctness and efficiency.

assessments.description: Weekly lab with short C programming and analysis tasks.

topics.name: Algorithm Foundations & Analysis
topics.description: Review of C tooling, algorithmic thinking, and asymptotic analysis used throughout the course.

subtopics.name: Course structure and tools
subtopics.description: People, expectations, and the C workflows used in COMP2521.

subtopics.name: Cost models and asymptotic notation
subtopics.description: Counting primitive operations and classifying growth using Big-O, Theta, and Omega.

subtopics.name: Reasoning about correctness
subtopics.description: Loop invariants, pre/post conditions, and when to benchmark.

contents.title: Week 1 Orientation & Analysis
contents.summary: Slides cover staff introductions, teaching modes, assessment overview, and a refresher on why we analyse algorithms in addition to benchmarking.

questions.prompt: When we talk about asymptotic notation (Big-O, Theta, Omega), what are we really doing?
choices: Predicting the exact running time for any input size.
Grouping algorithms by how fast their running time grows, while ignoring constant factors and tiny lower-order terms.
Describing only recursive algorithms.
Measuring memory use but not time.
questions.explanation: Asymptotic notation focuses on the dominant growth term so we can compare how algorithms scale without worrying about constant factors.

questions.prompt: Why do we still analyse an algorithm if we can run a quick benchmark?
choices: Benchmarks always fail on modern hardware.
Analysis lets us predict behaviour on any input size, not just the small samples we happened to measure.
Benchmarking is illegal in UNSW labs.
Analysis only matters for recursive programs.
questions.explanation: Benchmarks can miss worst cases or larger inputs, whereas analysis lets us reason about growth for any input size.

questions.prompt: What does a loop invariant help us prove?
choices: That the compiler will optimise the loop.
That the loop maintains a key property every time it iterates so the final result is correct.
That the loop will always terminate.
That the loop uses no extra memory.
questions.explanation: Loop invariants capture a property that stays true each iteration and support a correctness proof.

questions.prompt: Why do we ignore constant factors when comparing Big-O classes?
choices: Constants never exist in code.
Constant factors do not change which algorithm grows faster for very large inputs.
Big-O cannot include numbers.
Because compilers remove all constants.
questions.explanation: For large inputs, growth rate dominates constants, so Big-O focuses on the term that grows the quickest.

questions.prompt: What is a good reason to profile (measure) code after doing asymptotic analysis?
choices: Big-O says everything about real run times.
Profiling can reveal constant-factor differences and implementation issues that analysis does not capture.
Profiling is required before writing pseudocode.
Analysis is only useful if profiling fails.
questions.explanation: Analysis gives growth trends, but profiling shows real constant factors and bottlenecks in actual code.

topics.name: Sorting Strategies
topics.description: Elementary sorting algorithms, divide-and-conquer techniques, and linear-time counting strategies.

subtopics.name: Elementary comparison sorts
subtopics.description: Selection, insertion, and bubble sort characteristics.

subtopics.name: Divide-and-conquer sorting
subtopics.description: Mergesort and quicksort recurrences, pivot choices, and stability.

subtopics.name: Counting and radix sorting
subtopics.description: When linear-time sorting applies and how digit-based methods work.

contents.title: Week 2 Sorting Notes
contents.summary: Slides discuss why we sort, detail the mechanics of simple sorts, and derive the mergesort recurrence T(n) = 2T(n/2) + n.

questions.prompt: Which recurrence matches the worst-case running time of mergesort on an array of size n?
questions.explanation: Mergesort splits the array in half, sorts each half, and merges in linear time, giving T(n) = 2T(n/2) + O(n).

questions.prompt: Why is insertion sort often faster than mergesort on tiny arrays?
choices: Insertion sort has O(1) complexity.
Small arrays make constant factors and memory overhead dominate, favouring the simple inner loop of insertion sort.
Mergesort cannot handle arrays under 10 elements.
Insertion sort uses parallel threads automatically.
questions.explanation: For small inputs, the overhead of recursion and extra arrays can outweigh the theoretical advantage of mergesort.

questions.prompt: What makes quicksort unstable in its basic form?
choices: It always uses the same pivot value.
Partitioning can swap equal keys and change their relative order.
It only works on arrays of integers.
It requires extra memory for stability.
questions.explanation: During partitioning equal keys can be placed on either side, breaking original ordering unless we add extra bookkeeping.

questions.prompt: When is counting sort a good choice?
choices: When keys are arbitrary strings.
When keys are integers in a small, known range.
When recursion is forbidden.
When we sort linked lists.
questions.explanation: Counting sort shines when the key range is small so we can count occurrences directly in linear time.

questions.prompt: What simple improvement helps quicksort avoid its worst-case behaviour?
choices: Always use the first element as the pivot.
Pick the pivot randomly or use median-of-three to avoid already-sorted inputs.
Swap the array halves before partitioning.
Use counting sort on every partition.
questions.explanation: Randomising or sampling the pivot reduces the chance of consistently uneven partitions.

topics.name: Abstract Data Types & Balanced Trees
topics.description: Stacks, queues, binary search trees, and AVL rotations for keeping trees balanced.

subtopics.name: Stack and queue ADTs
subtopics.description: LIFO vs FIFO behaviour and common use cases.

subtopics.name: Binary search tree operations
subtopics.description: Recursive insertion, search, join, split, and deletion scenarios.

subtopics.name: AVL balancing
subtopics.description: Rotation patterns (LL, RR, LR, RL) to keep tree height logarithmic.

contents.title: Week 3 ADTs & AVL Trees
contents.summary: Slides introduce abstraction, present stack/queue behaviours, revisit BST traversal, and step through AVL rebalancing with diagrams.

questions.prompt: If you push the numbers 1, then 2, then 3 onto a stack, in what order do they come back out when you pop?
questions.explanation: A stack is last-in, first-out, so the last pushed value (3) pops first, followed by 2 then 1.

questions.prompt: What property must always hold for a binary search tree?
choices: Every node has at most two children.
All keys in the left subtree are smaller than the node's key, and all keys in the right subtree are larger.
The tree is perfectly balanced.
Every level is fully filled.
questions.explanation: BST ordering requires left subtree keys to be less, right subtree keys to be greater, enabling binary search.

questions.prompt: An AVL tree becomes unbalanced in a left-right (LR) pattern. What fix do we apply?
choices: Do one left rotation at the parent node.
Do one right rotation at the parent node.
Rotate the left child to the left, then rotate the parent to the right.
Rotate the left child to the right, then rotate the parent to the left.
questions.explanation: An LR imbalance needs a double rotation: left rotation on the left child, then right rotation on the parent.

questions.prompt: Why can an AVL tree guarantee efficient search?
choices: It is always perfectly balanced.
Its height stays logarithmic in the number of nodes by restoring balance after each update.
It only stores sorted arrays.
It uses hashing for lookups.
questions.explanation: AVL rotations ensure the height grows like log n, so search costs stay logarithmic.

questions.prompt: What is a common use for a queue in algorithms?
choices: Tracking recursion depth.
Breadth-first search exploration order.
Storing sorted data.
Evaluating postfix expressions.
questions.explanation: BFS uses a FIFO queue to visit nodes level by level.

topics.name: Graph Theory & Traversal
topics.description: Graph terminology, adjacency representations, and traversal strategies such as BFS and DFS.

subtopics.name: Graph basics
subtopics.description: Vertices, edges, directed vs undirected, and real-world examples.

subtopics.name: Representations
subtopics.description: Adjacency matrices versus lists and their trade-offs.

subtopics.name: Traversal patterns
subtopics.description: Breadth-first and depth-first search behaviour.

contents.title: Week 4 Graph Fundamentals
contents.summary: Slides motivate graphs through real examples, formalise terminology, and compare adjacency list and matrix storage.

questions.prompt: You need the shortest path in an unweighted graph. Which traversal finds it every time?
choices: Depth-first search
Breadth-first search
Pre-order traversal
Random walk
questions.explanation: BFS explores the graph layer by layer, so the first time you reach a node you have the minimum number of edges.

questions.prompt: What is an advantage of an adjacency list over an adjacency matrix?
choices: It always uses more memory.
It stores only the edges that actually exist, saving space on sparse graphs.
It allows O(1) edge checks.
It removes the need for edge weights.
questions.explanation: Adjacency lists only store neighbours, so sparse graphs use much less memory compared to n√ón matrices.

questions.prompt: Which scenario best suits a depth-first search?
choices: Finding shortest unweighted paths.
Checking if a graph has a cycle or exploring all possible paths.
Scheduling tasks by urgency.
Comparing edge weights.
questions.explanation: DFS naturally dives down paths and is great for detecting cycles, topological sorting, and exploring all possibilities.

questions.prompt: What does it mean for a graph to be directed?
choices: Edges have a direction, so (u, v) is different from (v, u).
Every edge has a weight.
The graph forms a tree.
Edges cannot cross.
questions.explanation: Directed graphs treat each edge as an ordered pair, so travel is only allowed in the specified direction.

questions.prompt: Why might we store vertex discovery and finishing times during DFS?
choices: To sort vertices alphabetically.
To classify edges (tree, back, forward, cross) and support algorithms like topological sort.
To measure memory usage.
To detect negative cycles.
questions.explanation: DFS timestamps reveal structure about paths and help with edge classification and topological sorting.

topics.name: Shortest Paths & Minimum Spanning Trees
topics.description: Weighted graphs, Dijkstra's algorithm, and strategies for building minimum spanning trees.

subtopics.name: Single-source shortest paths
subtopics.description: Dijkstra's algorithm and relaxation invariants.

subtopics.name: Minimum spanning trees
subtopics.description: Prim's and Kruskal's algorithms compared.

subtopics.name: Cut and cycle properties
subtopics.description: Why greedy picks work for MSTs.

contents.title: Week 5 Shortest Paths & MSTs
contents.summary: Slides walk through Dijkstra with a priority queue and detail how cuts and cycles justify Prim's and Kruskal's choices.

questions.prompt: For Dijkstra's algorithm to work the way we wrote it, what must be true about the edge weights?
choices: Every edge must have weight 1.
Edges can be negative as long as there are no cycles.
All edge weights must be zero or positive.
The graph has to be a tree.
questions.explanation: Dijkstra assumes distances only decrease in a predictable way, which is only safe when all weights are non-negative.

questions.prompt: Which structure do we rely on in Prim's algorithm to pick the next cheapest edge?
choices: A max stack
A priority queue / min-heap
A basic FIFO queue
A sorted adjacency matrix
questions.explanation: Prim's algorithm keeps a min-heap of candidate edges keyed by weight so we can grab the cheapest connection to the current tree.

questions.prompt: What does "relaxing" an edge mean in shortest path algorithms?
choices: Removing the edge from the graph.
Checking whether going through this edge gives a shorter path and updating the distance if it does.
Swapping the edge direction.
Setting its weight to zero.
questions.explanation: Relaxation compares the current best distance with the distance through a neighbouring edge and keeps the smaller value.

questions.prompt: Why does Kruskal's algorithm sort edges by weight first?
choices: To ensure the graph becomes directed.
So it can consider the lightest edges first and build an MST greedily.
To remove heavy edges from the graph.
Because sorting is required by Dijkstra.
questions.explanation: Kruskal's algorithm grows an MST by adding the next lightest edge that doesn't form a cycle.

questions.prompt: What does the cut property tell us about MSTs?
choices: Every cut must contain exactly one edge.
The lightest edge crossing any cut can safely be part of some MST.
Cycles must be avoided at all costs.
The graph must be connected only after building the tree.
questions.explanation: The cut property justifies why choosing the smallest crossing edge keeps us on track for an MST.

topics.name: Hash Tables & Dictionaries
topics.description: Implementing the map ADT, designing hash functions, and managing collisions with chaining.

subtopics.name: Map ADT operations
subtopics.description: Insert, lookup, and delete key-value pairs.

subtopics.name: Hash function design
subtopics.description: Spreading keys evenly and keeping load factor under control.

subtopics.name: Chaining collision handling
subtopics.description: Linked-list buckets and when to rehash.

contents.title: Week 8 Hash Tables
contents.summary: Slides revisit the map ADT, show examples of good hash functions, and demonstrate chaining with real code snippets.

questions.prompt: What is the goal of a good hash function?
choices: Produce the same value for every key.
Spread keys evenly across buckets so chains stay short.
Sort the keys as they arrive.
Create longer linked lists.
questions.explanation: Even distribution keeps chains short and operations near constant time.

questions.prompt: If a chaining hash table starts to show very long buckets, what can we do?
choices: Do nothing; performance cannot improve.
Resize the table with more buckets and recompute the hash for every key.
Switch each bucket to a stack.
Delete half of the entries.
questions.explanation: Rehashing into a larger table reduces load factor and shortens the chains.

questions.prompt: What does the load factor of a hash table measure?
choices: How many hash functions you use.
The average number of entries per bucket (items divided by buckets).
Whether keys are sorted alphabetically.
The depth of recursion in hashing.
questions.explanation: Load factor tells us how crowded the table is so we can decide when to rehash.

questions.prompt: Which data structure do we usually use inside each bucket when chaining?
choices: A linked list or dynamic array of key-value pairs.
A binary search tree.
A priority queue.
A postfix calculator.
questions.explanation: Chaining typically uses linked lists (or sometimes dynamic arrays) to hold the colliding entries.

questions.prompt: What is a common downside of chaining compared with perfect hashing?
choices: Chaining cannot handle string keys.
Worst-case lookups can degrade to O(length of the chain).
Chaining requires every key to be unique.
Chaining forces us to rebuild the table every insert.
questions.explanation: If many keys fall into the same bucket, a lookup may walk a longer chain, so we monitor load factor to keep chains short.

topics.name: Priority Queues & Tries
topics.description: Using binary heaps for priority queues and storing string sets with tries.

subtopics.name: Binary heap mechanics
subtopics.description: Maintaining the heap invariant and running heapsort.

subtopics.name: Decrease-key and scheduling
subtopics.description: Adjusting priorities and bubbling values.

subtopics.name: Trie operations
subtopics.description: Insertion, lookup, and autocomplete behaviour.

contents.title: Week 9 Priority Queues & Tries
contents.summary: Slides demonstrate heap push/pop, show how decrease-key works, and motivate tries for predictive text and dictionary lookups.

questions.prompt: We decrease a key inside a binary heap priority queue. How do we fix the heap afterward?
choices: Swap the node with its larger child over and over.
Rebuild the whole heap from scratch.
Bubble the node up while it is smaller than its parent.
Run mergesort on the underlying array.
questions.explanation: After decrease-key we bubble the node toward the root until the parent is no longer greater.

questions.prompt: Why does a binary heap make a good priority queue implementation?
choices: Insertions and removing the minimum both run in logarithmic time while using only an array.
It sorts the entire array automatically.
It stores elements in sorted order all the time.
It only works for integers.
questions.explanation: Heaps support efficient insert and delete-min operations and can be stored compactly in an array.

questions.prompt: Ignoring alphabet size, how long does it take to look up a word of length L in a trie?
choices: O(log L)
O(L)
questions.explanation: The lookup follows one edge per character, so the cost grows linearly with the word length.

questions.prompt: What is the main trade-off when using a trie instead of a hash table for storing words?
choices: Tries use more memory but can answer prefix queries quickly.
Tries only work for numbers.
Tries cannot insert new keys after building.
Tries always require sorting.
questions.explanation: Tries store characters along paths, which can cost more memory but allows fast prefix lookup and autocomplete.

questions.prompt: What does heapsort do after it builds a heap from the input array?
choices: Removes the minimum repeatedly, placing each element at the end of the array.
Switches to quicksort.
Runs insertion sort on the heap.
Rebuilds the heap multiple times with random pivots.
questions.explanation: Heapsort turns the array into a heap then repeatedly extracts the min (or max) and writes it to the end of the array to produce a sorted order.
